conclusion: Determine the propagation time of light in the prism.
The prism is isosceles with vertex angle 30°, side length AB = L, light hits midpoint O of AB at 45°, exits perpendicular to AC.
Light enters prism at O and exits perpendicular to AC.
Light travels along the normal to AC.
Distance traveled in the prism can be found using geometry.
Snell's Law relates angles of incidence and refraction: n1 sin i = n2 sin r.
Refractive index n2 can be found using given angles and Snell's Law.
Speed of light in the prism v = c/n2.
Propagation time t = d/v.
Light enters at O and exits perpendicular to AC.
Distance from O to point of exit can be calculated using trigonometry.
Given i = 45° and light exits perpendicular to AC, angle of refraction r is 0°.
Using Snell's Law: 1 * sin 45° = n2 * sin 0°, implies n2 is undefined, suggesting a different approach.
Light travels along the normal to AC, traveling a distance equal to the height of the prism.
Height h of the prism can be calculated using the geometry of the isosceles triangle.
Height h of the isosceles triangle with base L and vertex angle 30° is h = L/2 * tan(15°).
Using tan(15°) = 2 - √3.
Speed of light in the prism v = c/n2.
Propagation time t = h/v = h * n2/c.
Final expression for propagation time: t = (L/2 * (2 - √3) * n2)/c.
